title: Text Based Adventure Game
description: Created a text-based RPG adventure game in Java that demonstrates strong object-oriented programming principles. The game features a comprehensive combat system, inventory management, equipment upgrades, and a shop interface. Players can equip different weapons with varying stats, use consumable items like health potions, and encounter boss enemies with unique abilities. The implementation showcases the ability to create complex interactive systems with multiple interconnected classes and maintain game state across various player actions.

The architecture follows a modular design with separate classes handling distinct gameplay elements - Player, Boss, Items, Balance, Strength, Level, and Equip - demonstrating an understanding of encapsulation and class relationships. Implemented sophisticated game mechanics including randomized encounters, variable attack patterns, and multiple progression systems. The shop system features dynamic pricing and inventory management, while the boss encounters include unique mechanics like identification systems and enrage abilities to increase challenge and engagement.

This project highlights proficiency in Java, including class design, user input handling, conditional logic, and state management across complex systems. The combat loop demonstrates the ability to create engaging gameplay through varied options and strategic choices. Implemented multiple subsystems that interact seamlessly, including an equipment system with different weapon types and effects, a currency system with upgrade paths, and a level progression system with key-based unlocks. The project shows the capability to develop complete interactive experiences with layered mechanics that provide both challenge and player agency.

title: Dice Simulator
description: Developed an interactive dice physics simulation application using Java Swing framework. The project features a realistic physics engine that simulates dice movement with gravity, collision detection, and bouncing mechanics. Implemented responsive dice that roll when triggered by user input (spacebar) and display appropriate dot patterns based on randomly generated values. The application renders two dice with accurate visual representations that interact naturally with screen boundaries and with each other through collision.

Enhanced the user experience through fluid animation achieved by implementing a consistent frame rate system and efficient refresh cycles. The simulation incorporates realistic physics behaviors including velocity changes, friction effects, and gravity simulation. Key technical achievements include collision detection algorithms, graphical rendering of dice faces with proper dot patterns, and an event-driven architecture to handle user input. The project demonstrates strong object-oriented programming principles with clear separation of concerns between physics simulation, rendering, and application control.

title: Asteroids
description: My first experience with Python. This project was during my first semester of college. It is a simple game where the player controls a spaceship to avoid crashing into asteroids.

title: Fractal Drawer
description: Developed a recursive fractal generation application in Java leveraging object-oriented principles to create visually complex patterns from simple geometric shapes. The program allows users to select from multiple base shapes (circles, rectangles, triangles) and generates intricate fractals through recursive function calls with precise position and size adjustments. Each implementation features dynamic color patterns based on recursion level and accurate area calculation functionality. The program incorporates custom shape classes, canvas rendering for visualization, and user input handling through command-line interface. This project demonstrates strong competencies in recursive algorithm design, geometric calculations, object-oriented programming, and creating interactive user experiences.

title: Text Based Battleship
description: Developed a console-based Battleship game application in Java featuring multiple gameplay mechanics and an interactive command-line interface. The program implements a robust architecture using object-oriented principles with a clear separation between the Game logic controller and Board representation. Key features include various attack options (standard fire, missile strikes, drone reconnaissance, and scanner functionality), customizable board dimensions, comprehensive gameplay statistics tracking, and an optional debug mode for development testing.

The implementation showcases strong software engineering practices including structured program flow control, input validation, user-friendly command options, and state management throughout the gameplay lifecycle. The modular design allows for flexibility in gameplay parameters while maintaining a consistent user experience through well-defined interface methods. Technical highlights include effective use of Java's switch expressions for command handling, object composition for game state management, and thoughtful implementation of game mechanics that create an engaging tactical experience for users.

title: Java Technical Description
description: Authored a comprehensive introduction to Java methods and their implementation for programming beginners. This technical documentation explains core concepts including access modifiers, return types, parameters, and method bodies with clear examples and structured organization.

Demonstrated technical writing skills by creating a well-organized manual that breaks down complex programming concepts into digestible sections. The document follows professional documentation standards with proper formatting, table of contents, and references.
Created for my Technical Writing course, this project showcases my ability to communicate technical information clearly while maintaining accuracy and readability for a beginner audience.

title: Linear Least Squares
description: A project created for my Linear Algebra class. This project uses the least squares method to find the best fit line for a set of data points.

title: Embedded Battery Simulator
description: Text based representation of a battery using bit level manipulations. The first part of the project was programmed in C. The second half of the project was converting that code to x86_64 assembly.

title: schottler3.github.io
description: This served as my first portfolio website. It was created using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. The website was never fully finished as I was learning web development as I was creating it. Upon completion of my web development class, I decided to start fresh and create a new website with modern frameworks with the original as a template for design.

title: Application Extension
tagline: Adding Features to an Existing Application
description: This was a class long project for Program Design and Development that extended the functionality of an existing application. The project was created in C++ and added features to a 3D model routing application.

title: Merkle Tree Generator
tagline: Splits Text Files into Blocks and Hashes
description: Program created for my operating systems class. This program reads a text file and splits it into blocks. The program then hashes the blocks and creates a Merkle tree.

title: File Structure Cleaner
tagline: Changes Duplicate Files to Symbolic Links
description: Given a directory, this program will search for duplicate files and change the duplicates to symbolic links. This project was created for my operating systems class.

title: Simple Website
description: Consisting of a couple of pages with information about me. This project was created for my Internet Programming class.

title: Schedule Website
description: Developed a fully functional HTTP web server using Python's http.server module to host a dynamic personal portfolio website. Implemented custom request handling for both GET and POST methods, enabling seamless navigation across multiple pages including a personal schedule, biography, and interactive event submission form. The server architecture efficiently manages static file delivery (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and images) with proper MIME type handling and includes robust error handling with custom 404 pages.

Engineered a dynamic form processing system that captures user input through POST requests, parses URL-encoded data, and generates real-time HTML table entries to display submitted events. The application demonstrates proficiency in server-side programming, HTTP protocol implementation, data parsing and validation, and full-stack web development principles. Successfully deployed the server on localhost:4131, providing a responsive and user-friendly interface for event management and personal content presentation.

title: Virtual Memory Management
description: Built for my second operating systems class, this project simulates a virtual memory management system. The program implements page fault handling and page replacement algorithms and tests their access patterns.

title: User Level Threads
description: Implemented using POSIX threads and C. This project was created for my second operating systems class. The project implements a user level thread library that allows for thread creation, joining, waiting, yielding, stopping, resuming, and termination.

title: Grocery List App
tagline: Ideation, Research, and Design of an App
description: Created for my User Interface and Design class. This project was a group project that involved ideation, research, and design of an app of our choosing. We chose to pursue a grocery list app. The project included a user study, data analysis, design process, AB testing, and final presentation.

title: Ray Tracer
tagline: A ray tracer Built From Scratch
description: This ray tracer is a comprehensive rendering engine built from scratch in C, implementing advanced computer graphics techniques to generate photorealistic images. The project supports multiple geometric primitives including spheres and various triangle types (flat, smooth-shaded, and textured), with full support for the Blinn-Phong illumination model. The renderer handles complex lighting scenarios with both directional and point light sources, calculating accurate shadows, reflections, and refractions. Key features include texture mapping with barycentric coordinate interpolation for triangles and spherical UV mapping for spheres, opacity-based transparency, and recursive ray tracing for realistic reflections and refractions using Fresnel equations and Snell's law.

The architecture demonstrates strong software engineering principles with modular design and efficient memory management. The renderer processes scene descriptions from configuration files, supporting materials with customizable diffuse and specular components, ambient occlusion coefficients, shininess values, and refraction indices. The implementation carefully tracks refraction index changes as rays pass through different media using a custom stack data structure, enabling accurate rendering of transparent and semi-transparent objects. The output is generated in PPM format, making it easy to view and process the rendered images. This project showcases proficiency in 3D mathematics, geometric algorithms, and low-level C programming while implementing production-quality rendering techniques used in modern graphics applications.

title: Website Redesign
description: A group project for my Web Design class. The project involved redesigning an ecommerce website. The project included a competitive analysis, user personas, wireframes, mockups, a redesign, and a final presentation.

title: Web Application Design
description: Looking at market competition, information hierarchy, and key features, I created my own design for a smart home assistance web application. This project was created for my Web Design class.

title: Rasterizer Project
description: Created for my graphics class. This project is a rasterizer that uses OpenGL in C++. The program takes in a 3D model file and renders the scene using rasterization. It then allows you to move around the scene and view it from different angles.

title: FriendCore
description: Created as a plugin for a Minecraft server that I play with friends on. This plugin adds a commands description board, elevators, server state voting, custom minecarts, and custom tools with special abilities.

title: Maze Search Comparison
tagline: Research Paper on Graph Search Algorithms
description: Implementation of graph search algorithms and comparison of their performance. This project was created for my Introduction to AI class. The project includes a research paper that compares the performance of BFS, DFS, Best First Search, Dijkstra's, and A* search algorithms. The user interface is hosted on a server and allows the user to select a start and end node or a random maze and run the algorithms.

title: TaskNext
description: This was a project done at the University of Minnesota as a personal assignment. The project was to create a todo website using Ember.js, Firebase, and Tailwind CSS. TaskNext uses Ember.js SPA framework to create a web application that is functional and easy to use. The website uses Firebase to store the data and to authenticate users. Tailwind CSS was used for all of the styling of the web app. The web app started as a fundamental project that didn't have any style requirements, but the more I coded it the more I fell in love with its overall design and functionality.

There are plenty of features that I would like to add to the website in the future. I would like to add more functionality with how you can filter or sort tasks as well as a calendar option to view tasks by a designated period of time. This project turned into a passion project and I am excited to see where it goes in the future.

I had never worked with Ember.js or any type of SPA framework before this project. I learned a lot about how to use Ember.js to render components and use tracked variables to have effective data binding. I also learned how to use Firebase to store data as collections and documents. Firebase also offered authentication services that I used to authenticate users. Firebase is easy to understand and the integration with GitHub Actions is seamless. I'm really happy I got to learn these new frameworks along with my newfound love for Tailwind CSS.

title: Culinary Cards
description: This website is unfortunately hosted on Render.com. This means that the website takes some time to spin up. The data in the database is wiped every month due to it being a free service. Render.com is able to do this by storing our Git repository information. After some time of inactivity, the website will spin down and the data will be wiped from their servers. This is a great service for hosting a website for free, but it is not ideal for a website that needs to store data for long periods of time.

The website is a recipe website that allows users to create, read, update, and delete recipes. The website is built using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. The website uses a PostgreSQL database to store the recipes. The backend is hosted in Flask with a frontend CSS framework of PureCSS.

This website was an excellent learning experience for me. I learned how to use a SQL database, how to use a backend server, and how to use a frontend framework. I also learned how to use Git to push and pull code from a repository as well as dealing with merge conflicts and other Git issues. The project heavily relied on my group's teamwork and communication skills. We got to work together to create the website and make sure that we were all on the same page. We had weekly meetings to discuss what we had done and what we were going to do. We also had a group chat to discuss any issues that we were having. This project was a great learning experience for me and I am glad that I was able to work on it with such an amazing team!

title: Tailwind CSS Demo
description: This was a University project where my team and I needed to research a tech stack component and present it to the class. My team and I chose to research Tailwind CSS. Upon researching Tailwind, we found that it was a utility-first CSS framework that was easy to use and had many features. We decided to create a demo website instead of a standard presentation. The website was built using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. The website was hosted using Ember.js. The website was a great learning experience for me. I learned how to use a new CSS framework and how to use Ember.js.

The interactive website utilizes core Ember.js concepts such as components and routes. The website is a great example of the basics of using Ember.js as well as providing real-time renders of the HTML/Tailwind code.

My team and I worked together to create the website. We had weekly meetings to discuss what we had done and what we needed to improve. In the end, we came together to record the presentation and my team member posted it on YouTube.

title: Globe Trotter
description: A travel diary web application with Ember.js, Firestore, and Firebase for real-time storage. Designed the UI with Tailwind CSS for a modern responsive design. Implemented features for users to log locations, add photos, tags, and people enhancing the user experience.

title: Personal Website
description: A portfolio website built with React and Next.js, hosted on Google Firebase. Designed to showcase my web development abilities and past projects through a clean, responsive interface.
Built with maintainability in mind, allowing easy updates for life events, projects, skills, and other content.
Implements modern web practices with responsive design, animations, and cross-device compatibility via Tailwind CSS.

title: Earthpol Insights
description: A comprehensive web application that serves as a community hub and information portal for the EarthPol Minecraft server. The application is built using Next.js with React and TypeScript, featuring a modern interface styled with Tailwind CSS and integrated with Firebase/Firestore for data persistence.

The core functionality centers around displaying detailed information about nations and towns within the EarthPol server ecosystem. Users can browse through an interactive list of nations, expand to view member towns, and access comprehensive pages showing statistics, player run shops, resident information, and geographical data. Each nation and town page includes rich details such as coordinates, founding dates, political relationships (allies/enemies), and an embedded interactive map. The application also displays player information with Minecraft skin avatars and provides visual representations of the server's political landscape.

The application serves as both an information resource for players wanting to learn about different nations, towns, and shops and a community building tool that helps server factions maintain their external presence through Discord integration. With features like real-time map embedding, comprehensive statistics tracking, and social connectivity, EarthPol Insights transforms raw server data into an engaging community platform that enhances the overall EarthPol Minecraft experience.

title: Artist Website Redesign
tagline: A recreation in progress of redesigning TeriSchottlerArt.com
description: This website was originally created to be functional and not stylistic. The current stack involves default CSS, Redux, React.js, Node.js, Cloudflare instance hosting with NoSQL storage options, and integration with Square for E-Commerce ability.

The redesign is porting over from that default CSS with a custom responsive design framework to Tailwind CSS to streamline the process and have a more cohesive theme. The change will also add more pages and take inspiration from other artists' websites to stay current and have the features the clientbase expects.
The current project link is live and contains the non-edited website as we will be moving to the design in the near future.

title: Amazon Updater
tagline: Automatic inventory and price updater for Superior Tool
description: Hosted on a RaspberryPi and scheduled to run once a day with a backend of Flask with Python in a Pip environment. The server does not have a frontend due to the nature of the tool. This will be updated in the future to allow for more functionality.

This internal tool is consuming an API by Great Lakes Tools and using that item data to assist with our item inventory and pricing. The system then uses the consumed data and applies our business logic of pricing based on UPS and USPS pricing tables and inventory. It then automatically updates the Amazon listings using the Amazon SP-API and logs the results as it goes.
The next step of this project is currently under development to use this data to also update Ebay Listings using the EBay Developer Portal
